text: look at this fine fine house on a
beautiful spring day here in New York
City welcome to the world science
festival science and story is our
mission what is science but the story of
our understanding of the world the story
of civilization on some level the story
of great discoveries and once ha I had
this dream and I was strand binging I
grabbed a bunch of books I went satin
park as I was sitting there in this park
suddenly the authors of the books that i
binge started to appear sean carroll IL
dr. Oh Joe Marchand joyce carol oates
and steven pinker of course that would
never happen anyway welcome to to the
right angle science and story thanks for
being here I'm always happy to be on a
panel with such an interesting and
intelligent people and the idea of the
world science festival is very exciting
and very appealing Joyce how would you
respond to the intersection of science
and your work as a novelist and
storyteller but both Edgar and I are
really chroniclers of American history
American culture this american life and
science is part of that but i think the
most exciting feature of science and the
19th century let's say is the is the
discovery of evolution or evolutionary
theory the idea that they brain operates
by the processing of information by
signals by codes by transformations is I
think an essential insight into
demystifying the fact that this
three-pound hunk of matter can be
intelligent if it turns out that
neurosciences can someday replicate the
brain in a
computer and there are some people i
think in Switzerland who would try to do
that now and even though it billions and
billions of connections are involved
their position is that the brain is
finite when that happens presumably when
we can replicate the brain it will have
consciousness I took a very depressing
quiz on the internet recently it was
they had 20 poems 10 of them had been
written by human beings and 10 of them
had been artificially intelligently
generated and usually I'm really good at
this but it was like 50 50 I could not
tell which poems have been written by
human beings it's actually not
completely clear whether the actual
subjective experience of being alive and
awake you know and aware and seeing red
and hearing middle C and tasting sour
and so on depends on being made of human
flesh that is whether you want to be a
meat chauvinist about consciousness or
whether it's a question of processing
patterns of information I think it's
also important for people to have the
two aspects of the mindset of science
that cuts across any subject on content
one of them is trying very hard to
determine whether what you believe is
true and to be very skeptical of your
own confidence in your own beliefs and
the other is to try to explain things to
not accept the answer because I said so
or because it sounds good
because we've always believed that to be
true or it just is and to look for
underlying causes to continually ask the
question why is it that way as opposed
to some other way
why did the three of you go from
scientific rigorous research to writing
what I was doing was too interesting to
keep to myself in my colleagues the
world was interested in how the mind
works and how language works and I
thought it's a part of my
responsibilities as a scientist and it's
professor to share it I'll admit that
it's just fun I you know it's fun to
write it's fun to share this excitement
but also when you're doing science
you're always at the edge of the stuff
we don't understand as a journalist
every week I get to talk to somebody who
spent their entire career getting to an
amazing exciting you know breakthrough
point and then I gets talked to them
about it whether you're reading fiction
or nonfiction or a memoir you basically
are starting out at a certain point and
then you are going to be a little
surprised yourself by what what develops
and that's the great excitement and the
thrill of writing and also really
